questions.text: A 25-year-old asymptomatic patient undergoes a routine lumbar spine X-ray for an unrelated complaint. The radiologist notices an incidental finding on the image. Which of the following findings would be inconsistent with spina bifida occulta?

choices.text: Tuft of hair or dimple over the affected area
Often asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging
Failure of vertebral arches to fuse with intact spinal cord and meninges
Visible sac with cerebrospinal fluid and neural elements protruding through a defect

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Visible sac with cerebrospinal fluid and neural elements protruding through a defect.

 

Explanation:

  • Spina bifida occulta is characterised by:
    • Failure of vertebral arches to fuse with the spinal cord and meninges remaining within the spinal canal (Option C).
    • It is often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on imaging (Option B).
    • External signs like a tuft of hair or dimple over the affected area (Option A).
  • In contrast, a visible sac containing cerebrospinal fluid and neural elements protruding through a defect (Option D) indicates spina bifida aperta, specifically myelomeningocele, not spina bifida occulta.

 

Feature

Spina Bifida Occulta

Spina Bifida Aperta

Visibility

No visible defect on the back

Visible lesion or sac on the back

Skin coverage

Skin covers the defect

Open lesion, skin discontinuity

Neurological symptoms

Usually asymptomatic

Often causes neurological deficits

Severity

Milder form

More severe form

Diagnosis

Often, incidental finding on imaging.

Apparent at birth or detected prenatally

Spinal cord involvement

Spinal cord and meninges remain within the spinal canal.

Neural elements may protrude through defect

Types

Single type
  • Meningocele
  • Myelomeningocele

Treatment

Often, it requires no treatment.

Usually, it requires surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation undergoes a routine ultrasound, which reveals a fluid-filled sac at the lower back of the fetus. Which statement about myelomeningocele is most accurate?

choices.text: Protrusion of meninges through a vertebral defect
Sac contains cerebrospinal fluid but no neural elements.
Better prognosis than other spina bifida types
Includes spinal cord tissue within the protruding sac.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Includes spinal cord tissue within the protruding sac.

 

Explanation:

  • Myelomeningocele involves the herniation of the spinal cord, meninges, and cerebrospinal fluid through a vertebral defect.
  • The presence of spinal cord tissue within the sac differentiates myelomeningocele from other forms of spina bifida, such as meningocele, in which only the meninges and cerebrospinal fluid are present in the sac without spinal cord involvement.

 

Feature

Meningocele

Myelomeningocele

Definition

Protrusion of meninges through a vertebral defect (Option A)

Protrusion of meninges and spinal cord through a vertebral defect (Option D)

Sac contents

Cerebrospinal fluid only.

Cerebrospinal fluid and neural tissue.

Neural involvement

No neural elements in the sac (Option B)

Spinal cord and/or nerve roots in the sac

Skin coverage

Often covered by skin

Usually not covered by skin (open lesion)

Neurological deficits

Typically mild or absent

Often severe

Hydrocephalus risk

Lower risk

Higher risk

Prognosis

Generally better (Option C)

Generally worse

Surgical complexity

Less complex

More complex

Long-term complications

Fewer

More frequent and severe

Associated anomalies

Less common

More common

questions.text: Which of the following medications, when taken during pregnancy, is most strongly associated with an increased risk of myelomeningocele in the developing fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Valproic acid

 

Explanation:

  • Valproic acid (anti-convulsant) is most strongly associated with an increased risk of myelomeningocele when taken during pregnancy.
  • Metformin, amoxicillin, and levothyroxine are not specifically associated with significantly increased myelomeningocele risk (Options A, C, and D ruled out)

 

Other drugs associated with increased risk of neural tube defects:

Medication

Primary Use

Valproic acid

Epilepsy, Bipolar disorder

Carbamazepine

Epilepsy, Trigeminal neuralgia

Phenytoin

Epilepsy

Topiramate

Epilepsy, Migraine prevention

Methotrexate

Cancer, Autoimmune diseases

Trimethoprim

Urinary tract infections

Sulfasalazine

Inflammatory bowel disease, Rheumatoid arthritis

Mycophenolate mofetil

Organ transplant rejection prevention

Isotretinoin

Severe acne

Lithium

Bipolar disorder

 

Protective Factors Against Neural Tube Defects: Folic acid supplementation before and during early pregnancy can significantly reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation type II?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Myelomeningocele

 

Explanation: Arnold-Chiari malformation type II is almost always associated with myelomeningocele, a severe form of spina bifida where the spinal cord and meninges protrude through a defect in the spine.

 

Feature

Chiari I

Chiari II

Myelomeningocele

Rare

Almost always present

Age at diagnosis

Often adolescence/adulthood

Usually, infancy or prenatal

Syringomyelia

Can occur

More frequent

Herniated structures

Cerebellar tonsils only

Cerebellar tonsils, vermis, brainstem

Hydrocephalus

Less common

Very common

 

 

Syringomyelia (Option A) is characterised by a fluid-filled cavity in the spinal cord and can occur in both type I and II Chiari malformations. It's more common in type II but not the most distinguishing feature.

 

Adult-onset headaches (Option C) are more commonly associated with Chiari malformation type I, which is often diagnosed in adolescence or adulthood.

 

Scoliosis (Option D): While this can occur in Chiari malformations, it's not the most distinctive or common feature of type II.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT part of the classic triad of Dandy-Walker malformation?

choices.text: Cystic dilatation of the fourth ventricle
Complete or partial agenesis of the cerebellar vermis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hydrocephalus

 

Explanation:

Hydrocephalus is not part of the classic triad of Dandy-Walker malformation.

 

Dandy-Walker Malformation:

  • Most frequent posterior fossa malformation and is due to the developmental failure of the fourth ventricle's roof.

  • The classic triad consists of:
    • Cystic dilatation of the fourth ventricle (Option A)
    • Complete or partial agenesis of the cerebellar vermis (Option B)
    • Enlarged posterior fossa with elevation of the tentorium cerebelli (Option C)
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Macrocephaly (most common manifestation).
    • Rapid head growth with prominent occiput.
    • Possible long tract signs and cerebellar ataxia.
    • Delayed motor/cognitive milestones.
  • Associated Anomalies: CNS abnormalities in 70% of cases, including:
    • Agenesis of posterior cerebellar vermis and corpus callosum
    • Cortical dysplasia
    • Polymicrogyria
  • Diagnosis: MRI is the imaging modality of choice
  • Treatment: Shunt placement for cystic cavity in patients with hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department after an RTA, reporting a sudden, severe headache described as the "worst headache of his life," accompanied by nausea, vomiting, neck stiffness, and photophobia. A CT scan of the brain is provided. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Trauma

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with the "worst headache of his life," with neck stiffness and photophobia, along with CT findings showing an amorphous substance that fills the subarachnoid spaces around the brain, are suggestive of Subarachnoid haemorrhage.
  • Trauma is the most common cause of SAH, followed by Rupture of Berry Aneurysm (Option B)

 

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage:

  • Causes:
    • Most common: Trauma
    • Ruptured Aneurysm: Most commonly located in the Circle of Willis.
    • Arteriovenous Malformation (AVM) (Option D)
    • Perimesencephalic SAH: Bleeding is confined to the basal cisterns due to venous bleeding and is associated with a better prognosis.
  • Risk factors:
    • Female sex
    • Hypertension (Option C)
    • Smoking & Cocaine use
    • Genetic disorders (e.g., adult polycystic kidney disease, Marfan syndrome)
  • Symptoms:
    • Thunderclap Headache: Sudden and severe headache.
    • Associated with Seizures (10%), Unresponsiveness (50%) and Vomiting (70%)
  • Diagnosis:
    • CT Scan: First-line imaging, effective within 12 hours of onset, and its sensitivity decreases after one week.
    • Fisher Grading for SAH on CT:

Grade I

No bleeding.

Grade II

Diffuse SAH with layers <1mm thick.

Grade III

Localised clots or SAH layers >1mm thick.

Grade IV

SAH minimal/absent, with intracerebral/intraventricular haemorrhage.

 

  • Lumbar Puncture: Used if CT is negative but SAH is suspected.
  • Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA): Gold standard for visualising aneurysms.
  • Management:
    • Surgical or endovascular intervention and addressing complications such as vasospasm and electrolyte imbalances.
    • Early and effective treatment is crucial for improving outcomes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with a sudden severe headache, brief loss of consciousness, nausea, and vomiting. Neurological examination shows decreased consciousness and mild focal deficits. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is provided. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

 

Explanation:

Given the clinical scenario and radiological findings showing a crescent-shaped blood collection that follows the brain's contours and crossing suture lines, the most probable diagnosis is Subdural Hematoma.

 

Features

Subdural Hematoma

Extradural Hematoma

(Option B)

Location

Between Dura and Arachnoid

Between Dura and Skull

CT Appearance
  • Crescent-shaped
  • Crosses suture lines
  • Biconvex or lens-shaped
  • Well-defined & Localized,
  • Won’t cross suture lines

Common Causes

Tearing of bridging veins, often due to blunt trauma / acceleration-deceleration injuries

Rupture of the middle meningeal artery or vein due to skull fracture or trauma

Onset

Develop over days to weeks; Acute SDH can occur rapidly

Usually develop rapidly

Management
  • Craniotomy / Craniectomy, if significant.
  • Conservative management for smaller, stable cases.
  • Burr hole drainage is preferred for significant chronic cases

Urgent surgical evacuation for significant or deteriorating cases.
 


 

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (Option C) typically causes sudden severe headache, often described as a "thunderclap," and is seen on CT as blood in the subarachnoid space, often with associated hydrocephalus. It does not usually present with the crescent-shaped lesions seen in SDH.

 

Periventricular Hemorrhage (Option D) is often associated with hypertension or trauma and is typically seen as part of a broader pattern of haemorrhage rather than isolated findings.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents with sudden onset of nausea, vomiting, and confusion. On examination, he has a decreased level of consciousness and neck stiffness. A non-contrast CT scan reveals subarachnoid haemorrhage. Which of the following statements about Berry aneurysms is not true?

choices.text: Associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan's syndrome.
Absence of smooth muscle and intimal elastic lamina.
Most commonly seen at the bifurcation of the vertebrobasilar arteries.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Most commonly seen at the bifurcation of the vertebrobasilar arteries.

 

Explanation:

  • Berry aneurysms are most commonly found at the bifurcations in the anterior circulation of the Circle of Willis, such as the junction of the anterior cerebral and anterior communicating artery, not at the bifurcation of the vertebrobasilar arteries.
  • It is the most common type of intracranial aneurysm.
  • Saccular & typically located in the anterior circulation of the Circle of Willis.
  • Common Sites: Junction of Anterior Communicating and Anterior Cerebral Artery (Most Common) > Bifurcation of MCA (2nd Most Common) > Junction of PCA and Internal Carotid Artery > Intracranial Carotid Bifurcation > Bifurcation of Vertebrobasilar (Option C)

  • Structural Features:
    • Absence of Smooth Muscle and Intimal Elastic Lamina (Option B)
    • Wall Composition: Thickened, hyalinised intima
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Ruptured Berry Aneurysm: Can cause subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) or intracerebral haemorrhage and the most common rupture site is the dome or apex.
    • Unruptured Berry Aneurysm: Usually asymptomatic and often discovered incidentally. (Option D)
  • Treatment:
    • Endovascular Coil Occlusion: Preferred method.
    • Surgical Clipping: Used if endovascular methods are unsuitable.
  • Complications:
    • Rebleeding
    • Hydrocephalus: Managed with an external ventricular drain.
    • Vasospasm: Treated with hypervolemia, induced hypertension, and medication.
  • Conditions Associated with Berry Aneurysms:
    • Fibromuscular Dysplasia (FMD)
    • Marfan’s Syndrome (Option A)
    • Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
    • Coarctation of aorta
    • Autosomal dominant Polycystic Kidney disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a recent dental infection presents with persistent headaches, fever, and confusion. He exhibits focal neurological deficits and seizures. The radiological findings are provided. Given his clinical presentation and imaging, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Initiate IV antibiotics and immediate surgical drainage
Start oral antibiotics and monitor with CT every 48 hours
Administer high-dose corticosteroids and supportive care
Begin antiepileptic medications and refer for op follow-up.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Initiate IV antibiotics and immediate surgical drainage

 

Explanation:

  • Given the history of a recent dental infection, along with imaging showing a ring-enhancing lesion in the frontal lobe and symptoms of fever, confusion, and seizures, the most likely diagnosis is a Brain abscess.
  • The mainstay treatment includes both surgical intervention and antibiotic therapy.

Brain Abscess:

  • High-Risk Groups:
    • Cyanotic heart disease
    • Immunocompromised individuals
  • Pathology:
    • Direct Spread: From air sinus infections or following brain surgery.
    • Hematogenous Spread: Typically associated with respiratory infections, endocarditis, or dental infections.
  • Symptoms include fever, confusion, seizures, focal neurological deficits and raised ICT.
  • Most common in the frontal lobe, but are also frequently found in the parietal lobe, particularly in cases of hematogenous spread.
  • Imaging:
    • CT Scan (Initial Choice): Shows hypodense oedema initially, progressing to a ring-enhancing mass as the abscess matures.
    • MRI (IOC): Identifies restricted diffusion

 

  • Management: (Mainstay: Surgery + Antibiotics)
    • Early Surgical Drainage: Essential for effective treatment.
    • Antibiotics: IV antibiotics are administered for approximately 6 weeks.
    • Prophylactic Anticonvulsants: Considered due to a high risk of seizures.
    • Multiple smaller abscesses: IV Antibiotics.
    • Steroids: Reduce oedema and alleviate symptoms of mass effect.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with a significant right-sided brain tumour. During the neurological examination, the patient exhibits left-sided weakness. Which of the following best accounts for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Kernohan notch phenomenon

 

Explanation:

  • Kernohan's notch phenomenon involves the compression of the contralateral cerebral peduncle due to a brain mass effect, leading to motor deficits on the opposite side.
  • Mechanism:
    • Cerebral Peduncle Compression: A brain mass, often associated with transtentorial or uncal herniation, exerts pressure on the contralateral (opposite side) cerebral peduncle.
    • Tentorium Interaction: This compression happens against the free edge of the tentorium cerebelli, creating an indentation or "notch" in the cerebral peduncle.

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Contralateral Hemiparesis: Due to damage to motor pathways in the contralateral cerebral peduncle.
    • Ipsilateral Ocular Symptoms: If the herniation affects the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) on the same side as the mass, it may lead to ipsilateral (same side) oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Brown-Sequard Syndrome (Option B) involves damage to one side of the spinal cord, leading to specific patterns of sensory and motor deficits which don’t match the brain tumor scenario.

 

Tullio Phenomenon (Option C) is associated with inner ear disorders causing dizziness and hearing problems, and it is not relevant to motor deficits from a brain tumor.

 

Uhthoff's Phenomenon (Option D) involves the worsening of neurological symptoms with heat in conditions like multiple sclerosis, which is not related to a brain tumor's mass effect.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a fall from a ladder. He has a GCS score of 9 (E2V3M4), and his right pupil is dilated and nonreactive. The CT scan shows a large right-sided subdural hematoma with a significant midline shift to the left. BP: 180/100 mmHg, HR: 52 beats/minute with irregular breathing patterns. Which type of brain herniation is most likely occurring in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Uncal herniation

 

Explanation:

The patient is most likely experiencing uncal herniation based on the following findings:

  • Large Right-Sided Subdural Hematoma: Creates a space-occupying lesion, leading to significant mass effect.
  • Significant Midline Shift to the Left: Indicates severe displacement of brain structures.
  • Dilated and Nonreactive Right Pupil: A classic sign of uncal herniation due to oculomotor nerve compression.
  • Decreased Level of Consciousness (GCS 9): Resulting from brainstem compression.
  • Signs of Cushing's Triad: Including hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular breathing, indicative of increased intracranial pressure.

 

Uncal herniation occurs when the medial temporal lobe (uncus) is displaced downward through the tentorial notch, compressing the ipsilateral oculomotor nerve and brainstem.

Subfalcine herniation(Option A) typically causes contralateral leg weakness but not pupillary changes.

 

Tonsillar herniation(Option B) primarily affects the lower brainstem and cervical spinal cord.

 

Upward transtentorial herniation(Option C) is rare and usually occurs with infratentorial lesions.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man undergoes emergent decompressive craniectomy for a large right hemispheric infarct with significant mass effect. Post-surgery, he remains comatose and, six hours later, develops pinpoint pupils and irregular breathing. A stat CT scan shows resolution of the midline shift but reveals new bilateral hyperdense lesions in the midbrain. What is the most likely explanation for these new CT findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Duret hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

  • The new CT findings are most consistent with Duret haemorrhage, characterised by small, linear or flame-shaped haemorrhages primarily in the midbrain and upper pons.
  • It is typically caused by the rapid displacement of the brainstem, which can occur due to significant mass effects or sudden changes in intracranial pressure, such as those seen after decompressive surgery.
  • This results from stretching and tearing the perforating branches of the basilar artery.
  • Clinically present with persistent coma, pinpoint pupils, and irregular breathing suggest brainstem dysfunction, suggesting brainstem dysfunction.

 

Contrast extravasation (Option A) would be unusual without recent contrast administration and typically doesn't present with bilateral midbrain lesions.

 

Hemorrhagic transformation of infarct (Option B): While possible, this would typically occur in the area of the original infarct (right hemisphere), not in the midbrain.

 

Hypertensive microbleeds (Option D) usually occur over time and are more commonly found in other areas of the brain, not specifically bilateral in the midbrain.
